Current letter to Munir and Dara, my cofounders at Bloom.pm a social impact accelerator and social enterprise support ecosystem: [[[
I’m writing to show you why I believe our systems emerge from our foundational beliefs and mindsets—about what the world is and what humans are. Like a dog that won't cross an electric fence, we are limited by our deepest assumptions, many of which are historically ingrained. The problem is that we have lost a way of relating to the world that honors quality and meaning over mere materiality, and I want to show you why reconnecting with that sense of depth helps us truly come alive. By coming alive and reconnecting with this lost way of seeing, we can build new kinds of systems that honor people as ends in themselves, not just means for achieving “impact,” “funding,” or “goals.”
Below, I’m going to walk you through:
Why emergent approaches matter more than rigid systems
Why our present mindset of “winners take all” and mastery is flawed
How honoring relationships, depth, and meaning (vs. breadth and metrics) can heal burnout
Why I think we can form a better foundation for Bloom.pm by coming alive first, then building systems
I’ll share the personal reflections, doubts, and inspirations that led me here. Then, I’ll remind you, in the end, what I told you.

Tell Them
Core Hypothesis: Systems Emerge From Our Foundational Beliefs
The suspicions I've been having about "winners take all" and that we can't take down the master's house with the master's tools are becoming clearer and clearer to me. I want to ensure that our work honors the non-instrumental nature of treating people as ends, not means to SDGs or impact, or stories to tell our donors. It's by doing the right things for the right reasons that we can be successful as human beings first, facing ourselves in the mirror. Honor and dignity are worth more than continued funding from donors who don't trust us to treat us well.
I am convinced that we need emergent approaches—good people and trust that they will do beautiful things—not good systems we attempt to shape people through. We are kind of limited by our foundational beliefs and understandings. Historically, these beliefs have led us to live in a way that is instrumental and transactional. We lost a different way we once had of seeing the world—one related to quality, to a sense of meaning, not just materiality.

Why Emergent Approaches Over Rigid Systems?
Even the idea that we can create systems of digital tools that scale and create an impact that is "out of our hands" is somehow missing something important. Our care and our connection are essential. We need to ensure that we are crafting something meaningful and beautiful—a system that honors the maker and the person using it, preserving their insight. There's something about relationship that we've been alienated from. We text instead of calling, we want to "blast" an email to thousands, and have systems with drop-offs at every stage instead of leaning into the connection and knowledge that grows from our spheres and through them to their spheres.
Through our connection with mentors, we can transmit these new ways of seeing and lived values—not as a list, but as a lived experience. This is how we can trust that they get it. We will know because we will see and feel it in our interactions with them. The idea that we can give a feedback form or an assessment and get answers from our mentors is only half right. They will only be able to share what they see with the eye of rationality. We need to see them with the eye of quality—the eye of Goodness, Truth, and Beauty—the eye that knows these things.

Critique of the “Winners Take All” Mindset
Developing skills and knowledge at the edge of our growth in the face of challenges means we need to be sincere about what we know and what we don't know, what we can do and what we can't. I believe that rushing into things because there is funding is a horrible reason to do something. What if we can get funding so people can know themselves, the world, and access what their hearts are calling them towards?
What if funding allowed us to go deeper, work with fewer, and support them as they worked it out, rather than pushing funding, expenditures, and movement that may be adding friction and doing a bunch of wrong things that'll need to be undone? With so much friction, we can certainly burn people out, as we've seen on our own teams. What are we really doing?

Relationships, Depth, and Healing Burnout
Then, we can have scalable systems where those people can impact others, rather than thinking about scale in breadth—showing how many people have jobs or planted trees. We need to get more comfortable with depth: how many people are having meaningful moments, finding their gifts, and sharing them in gratitude, making a more sincere, honest, and beautiful change versus one which has "good impact." Impact—the sound of a heavy book hitting the floor or an asteroid on the earth—reminds me of "fail fast and break things" and disruptive technologies. We don't need to be disruptive in these days; things are disruptive enough. We need to be a source of healing.
Why do we talk about wellbeing and stress? What if we aligned ourselves more humbly, took on projects that gave us deep connection, and built real community by helping everyone slow down enough to have community? We can move fast later when fast is what wants to happen. I know this sounds idealistic, and I know you worry about the business failing, and that's okay. I sort of think that business might need to go.

Foundational Beliefs and Historical Context
I don't know if you believe, as I do, that good things live and true things find their homes. If we don't focus on what we "can do to keep going" and truly focus on the problem that moves us and what brings us to life sincerely, if we are "eating our own dogfood," I think we'll find something. It might be small—who knows, maybe a team of two or three for a while—although I don't think that's so bad.
What if we found ways to help Bloom be a business we "want to do" rather than "have to do"? Perhaps we need to find other jobs to give us time to build the real thing we want to share with the world. Maybe we need time to reflect and can work like Einstein did at some desk job somewhere so we can think. Maybe our children happening, our contracts dwindling, isn't the time to rush. Maybe these are signs (if you believe in those things—perhaps you'd prefer signals) that we should slow down and think deeper. It's what I've been doing.

Personal Reflections: Coming Alive
I've been thinking about our time in Turkey and the idea of coming alive that was starting to come into resolution for me there. The ideas that there was something weird about helping people have goals for social change and getting them to take on the "habits and best practices to help them be most effective"—it's possible that I'm wrong, yet I think it's clearer than ever to me that this is not something I'm willing to subjugate. Initially, I thought I could draw on the "depth" of things, and the systems would help scale out to the "breadths" of things—that wellbeing and welldoing were possible to bring together in a harmonious balance.
Externally, that may be what people see when they witness someone like my friend Dug Song build businesses while being a family man, not leaving Detroit for Silicon Valley, and still skateboarding while building a business that sells for 2.x billion dollars. I think that this is not an accident and that it was not a set of systems that he took on or books he read. The idea of "habits of success" is so instrumental to me. If you think about it, you will use your will to compel your mind and body into specific patterns of behavior to achieve a goal. Your mind and body have become instruments for this goal. Is the goal worth it? Why do you think there's burnout, alienation, and why do you think even in the social sector there are bad actors who believe that the ends justify the means?

Relationality, Love, and Meaning as Ends
It's taken me a long time to accept the lessons I was given when I was younger, inspired by Father Greg Boyle. When they asked his intentions for doing his social enterprise, he didn't give some SDG that needed to be addressed or some "God told me to do it" nonsense. He said because they were his friends. Relationality, closeness, love, connection, and care—these are all ends, reasons to do things that no one should have to justify and might be impossible to justify because they are not perceived by the eye of rationality. They are perceived by the eye that knows what goodness is, what truth is, and what beauty is. That eye is the one that I would like to cultivate.
The Nietzsche quote, "He who has a strong enough why can overcome any how," guides me here. People who love have climbed mountains—"there ain't no mountain high enough," "there ain't no ocean vast enough"—to keep them away from the beauty they want to do. This is a real reason, a source of persistence, vitality, and passion to knock on a thousand doors until one opens. This is why they'll leave our heart-based aliveness-focused program and join Y Combinator to get what they need financially or figure something totally new and unexpected out.
I'm finally able to see why I care so much about community, the upside-down pyramid, starting with why, character strengths, and coming alive. It's not about some materialist interpretation of mindfulness-based stress reduction for people to better manage their emotions to do the nonsense they have committed to doing. It's about coming to view emotions as messengers, to look through them into the place they touch your heart. Why do we feel sad when we see animals going extinct? What about that is meaningful for us that's being lost? Think about it, feel into it, see what echoes within you. Those emotions are treasures, and we are constantly being played by a masterful orchestra.

Emotions as Messengers of Meaning
Each tense emotion tells us something about a blocked source of meaning. Each positive emotion is a gift to enjoy, persist, and sink into what we're doing without being attached. Contentedness is not an emotion; it's a state. I believe these states are profoundly important to the idea of why we should be doing things and can be found when we tap into our sources of meaning, come alive, and heed their calls with small, bold actions. Similar to the zone described by the flow state, where our skills are at the edge of our capacity and the challenge we're at, we can gradually find the next emerging way of being by responding to the constant flow of calls.

Where the Current System Falls Short
This means trust, implies process, and moves people, businesses, projects, and more from a system of semi-static parts to an alive, organic whole that cannot be segmented, assessed with forms, analyzed, projected into the future, and planned. It's the reality that it's hubris to think otherwise. It's part of the insanity about why the iNGOs are more than happy to give us jobs, yet are silent when it comes to keeping us alive (Palestinians and Lebanese). We saw how let down the people who can see this hypocrisy felt. It's so true though—the goals, the SDGs, the plans—these things are dead on arrival. The reality of being responsive, being real, being caring, being human and humane is lost to the organizations focused on the attainment of something.
I know this all probably sounds crazy. In fact, I'm confident that since you've known me long enough, you might accept it a bit more. Yet for me, it took a while to finally deconstruct a few things, starting with Aristotle and the idea of classification. Aristotle’s metaphysics focus on cause-and-effect relationships (final cause, material cause) percolate like water through the grounds of Western culture and get amplified by the mechanistic thinking of the Scientific Revolution (Descartes, Newton). It's just a brain watching a world of parts interact—sort of system thinking, Hobbes. Oh crap, Christians are killing each other; we're totally horrible, and we need a rational government to put things in order. Systems should be what we follow, not people. Enlightenment off with his headism, individualist pieces that can reason best for themselves, laden with democratic American ideas like "let's pick happiness as a teleological conclusion," etc.

Historical Roots and a Lost Way of Seeing
We live in a soulless world of rational objects, bodies needing food, cause-effect transactions in a swirl of beautiful elegance making a souffle out of anthropology, biology, chemistry, physics, and the mathematics that Galileo said is the perfect way to describe the world. It can all be displayed as a nice little infographic—the world is made of markets transacting materiality. The hard problem of consciousness is irrelevant when we have people dying of malaria, and we go fix that because death is bad. What about not living at all, not coming alive, becoming a machine, giving up your ability to sense meaning and connect to true purpose for some fear-based worry your philosophical forefathers (that most have no idea about or understand the impact of the history of ideas) had?
We're here because of someone else's war, freaking people out. Our systems destroy the planet due to seeing humans as human resources for a machine that's efficiently transforming materiality into material to satisfy the needs and desires of humans. If there aren't enough desires to create enough demand to necessitate the improvement of the systems and optimization to achieve goals more efficiently, because hey, what rational person wouldn't want cheaper tomatoes? Who cares if we breed them to be transported across the ocean and have no idea what that does to the flavor, let alone nutritional profile?

It’s About Our Way of Seeing, Not Just Different Goals
We must use these fear-based epistemologies and ontologies that see the world full of nasty, brutish people who will die shortly unless we use our reason to align with the reason of the natural world, to break it up into little pieces and use it to our favor. And BTW, the people who think like this are more likely to be skiing in the Alps and owning businesses than running them. Also, their kids don't go to public schools and get graded like screws and meat of varying quality. By the way, I'm more of a B/B+ sort of person than a Grade A, so here, doing this thinking is a bit out of my weight class. Yet I digress, and I try anyway to help you see, feel, and understand this foundational thing.
It's NOT about the wrong goals, profit or SDGs. It's not even about the systems leveraging personal and professional growth to help transform the economic system into one that's better for people and the planet. No, it's about the way of seeing and understanding what a person is, what the world is, and the systems that emerge from that understanding.

Reconnecting With Meaning for New Systems to Emerge
Our neoliberal order is sort of a beautiful system that is hard to argue with. Market efficiency sort of works, as does reductionist science as we break atoms further down into their core. We can understand the material and superficial world and can move things, energy, resources, and food—all commodities—which the markets manage, valuing perfectly well. The problem is there is no reason for this elegant dance of a billion buy-sell decisions mostly run by machines. There is only short-sighted efficiency of materiality.
I've tried not to say God in this run-on paragraph. Yet it's a bit hard not to, so how about you look at your favorite person, a loved one, and convince yourself they are a "user" of Instagram, a customer of Zara, or a citizen of a country—little pinballs bouncing around in the systems of goals and accomplishments of others. What about your feeling of love? That's some oxytocin and some serotonin floating around a bloodstream in a body that wants to keep its bodily integrity intact so that it can propagate itself and not die. You cannot learn Darwin's theory and believe it without hurting your soul a little bit. There are people who die for beauty—don't you know? There are things that matter more than life itself. You know this; you may have even felt this if you're lucky. Yet we have no way in our modern mindset to understand it, where we can place it, what power this is that is ultimately lost.
These things have been bugging me for a long time. I started in education, realizing the issue with the control systems being forced on children—full of aliveness and dreams, shaping them into consumers and workers. I saw the post-WWII economic system require us to win the war of ideas and ensure that capitalism produces power and material success, and we did it at our own expense. Sure, this is all fine, said typing on a MacBook Pro made by a capitalist company with $216 billion in cash reserves, benefiting from the international trade that brings me coffee from Ethiopia to my door and markets that pressure countries to fight on my behalf so everything is affordable and safe.
Yet I think it doesn't have to be revolutionary. I think the simple act of finding that part of us that can see and feel what beauty and goodness are and asking it what it needs to shine and doing that—a little each day. Weirdly enough, for me, it's writing you this long letter. I was going to use AI to help clean it up and summarize and make it all polished, yet somehow I think that goes against my point here. We need to see each other, even our messy selves. This is from my heart to yours. I'm writing this with you, Dara, and you, Munir, in mind.
It's been a long struggle for me, starting before 2022 in Turkey—where I've felt off, yet I acquiesced, allowing my doubt in my own feelings to fester. I thought maybe he's right. Maybe we can keep doing/building this way. Maybe I'm wrong. Maybe there's a productive tension. I mentioned these ideas of coming alive in the retreat, although I think I didn't realize at the time that that's the foundational thing I want to do—the upside-down pyramid, self-efficacy, character strengths, notes journal, breakout rooms, one-on-ones, the 1% better journey were about that. Goals can come not from a dream of a desired future state, but they can emerge from becoming the kind of person who achieves that goal. Don't plan to run a marathon; become a runner. We've talked about these.
Yet more foundationally, this clarity shows me the kinds of things to focus on: we should measure at the end of the day and attend to our sources of meaning at the start. The story of self and the story of the world can and must be discovered and grown so we can allow our qualitative witnessing to see, echo, resonate with, and inspire knowledge and action. Togetherness matters, being a mirror matters, finding emotions is precious, discerning between emotions and states matters, goals can be had, yet ways of being we admire are what we must engender and practice. We can go slow, be gentle with ourselves, and be successful once we start on the path to self-knowledge and alignment with values, perception, and enaction.
I think sometimes you must think that I'm crazy, and perhaps I am. Although I'm working on developing my ideas, gathering stories (microfinance was beautiful, right? Amu Yunus got a Nobel Prize, cool? Well, we're seeing the fruits of not foundationally changing the perception of what finance is, what money is, what it serves. What a human is with a spate of suicides as a result of not being able to pay the petty sum back and being hounded by people who are achieving "targets"—targets, pretty grim).
I'm working on developing this into a clearer vision of what I think my work in "social impact" can be, what I think the problems are of burnout and lack of wellbeing. And no, it's not only because we don't have money for paid holidays; there's something burning about using yourself for something that is not yourself. We can cultivate gardens of conditions—we must treat people as ends and get close. Relationships matter, commitment matters, connection matters. Scale can happen in a beautiful and authentic way, probably not in the way we plan, where we draw hockey stick charts and hope and hope again.
I sometimes think perhaps I've been saved from success because I'm not sure I would have had the time, perspective, and frustration, quite frankly, to see as I do. Am I just "sourgraping" this whole thing? I don't think so. I think indigenous economics—talking about cyclical time (not linear) thinking, seven generations (not retiring when I'm 40), relationships with a world of meaning (not humans and nature as resources to extract)—are similar. Yet indigenous economics stays small and sort of implies we must take their principles and ways of doing things rather than discovering them ourselves in our own indigeneity—our Lebanese indigenous economics—emerging from systems built by people who have reintegrated both eyes, seeing with reason and logic and the eyes of meaning and quality. Being confident enough to know we need to be wary of too much planning in an era of collapse. We need to live in a way that when the bombs drop or the seas start rising, we are confident we did what we were made to do and were successful at every step of the way, no matter if we arrived wherever we thought we might or not.

Remind Them of What We Told Them
So there you have it. I’ve told you about:
How our systems emerge from deep-seated beliefs and mindsets
Why emergent approaches and depth of relationship matter more than quick, scalable fixes
How transactional and instrumental thinking leads to burnout, while real connection can heal and help us come alive
Why the historical context of our beliefs has stripped us of a sense of meaning and how reconnecting with that meaning might guide us forward
I hope this short essay made some sense. I wanted to share this to see if you have feedback, what gaps were in my logic. I think this is what I want to do next for work: to operationalize this process of first recognizing the perceptual faculty that we're being gaslit not to identify (artists usually are pretty clear about this, good ones at least). That faculty can see things and know things that are both reliable and true—just as reason can see and we can deduce truth, we can do that with quality as well.
By finding that and living it more in our lives, we come alive, and by coming alive we bring energy and goodness, building capacity, skills, relationships, knowledge, stories of self, stories of world—essentially forging a new foundation for new systems to emerge. We all need to awaken the artist within us to help us weave a more beautiful story that is just as true, and perhaps more true, to undo the fragility of systems and unearth the beauty and humility of emergence.
I don't think I intend to "get by" anymore with my work. I have to share what I know, or I shrivel up and help no one. I remember being asked in 2016 to make an entrepreneurship program, and I thought it was silly to have everyone do the same assignments. I thought it would be cool to direct people to the things they needed with technology. Today, I'm going back again and having another one of those moments where I can't do the same thing anymore. I need to do something different, something beautiful, and I'd love to do it with you—if you're in with me :)

Warm regards,
Bilal Ghalib
]]]
A personal essay showing my experience with beauty, struggle accepting inner quality recognition and my path towards integration: 
[[[Okay, so we're going to be writing an essay with our voice because one of my skills and competencies and something that I pride myself in is my ability to follow a thread clearly and coherently and articulated, and this content must be mine and come from my heart and not be external and also it must be connected to all realities. It's my intention that this becomes a snapshot of my thinking about the truths that I've discovered in my life and the realities they imply towards a good life and how that impacts the sense of speed, rush, fear, otherness, alienation, and impending disaster with the climate, the wars the mistrust of our neighbors and the lack of time and space and knowledge of what to do with ourselves. I'm indebted to my mom who shared with me in October of 2011 their aid prayer from Mecca, and in that prayer there was a talk and in that talk the speaker, shared the idea that God is beautiful, and he loves that which is beautiful and in that time, I was very hurt and unable to accept all of the tradition that I had been raised with because it was getting in the way of me trusting my heart, and that tension the reality that this person I respected and admired was some one that my heart honestly could lean towards and brought me aliveness was fighting with the textual reality of the lack of an articulated Islam or Christianity that I could check some box in an accounting system with the god and with my family to say that this woman is a Muslim and therefore I am allowed to have these feelings. rather than the fear, hope, trepidation, openness, wonder anticipation heart opening heart racing, mind spinning possibility, of accepting love.  I remember laying down on the ground outside and she asked me, do you love me? and rather than taking a moment to take a deep breath to look inside of my heart, and to say the truth of what I found, I deflected. I asked for literalism.  I asked how do you define love? There are places within us that know love that can distinguish love from lust and in my confusion and desire to be confused to avoid the pain and the stress and the fear of confronting my family and confronting the check box guard and religion that I had invented that wasn't the true way of interpreting are the only way I deflected and created confusion in my life and compounded that confusion for years and years I allowed myself in that confusion to create a shadow and to have the part of me that was alive to live in that shadow. I nook out of the house in the dark to be able to be with the parts of me that were actually alive and I lived like a zombie, having not slept and like a zombie because in the day I was living waiting for the night distant from my heart, distant from the thing that knows the truths of the world and the truths within myself. and in October 2011 I was given one of the keys of a trifecta that allowed me to open my heart and to connect reintegrate with my emotions, with my feelings, with my perception of beauty, with my sense of meaning and sense of self, and ultimately, at long last, the realizations that beauty is the splendor of truth. and beauty is that which draws you into love, and that the perception and recognition of beauty is a part of a faculty that is inextricable from that perception and that reality.  This faculty within us that sees beauty is the place where we can answer the questions of what is true and the confusions that we might have about what is actually good How should we live? What is real? My background as someone who loves science and technology and philosophy and rationalizations.  I think connects to this desire for control and this lack of engaging with the fear and the reality of the bird that when it wakes up and opens its eyes and sees its hungry children, and leaves its nest in fear and hope, seeking the worms, the seeds, the sustenance and the awe in the wonder and the gratitude and the aliveness at finding it. This way of seeing the world and living in the world requires both eyes, we do have a rational faculty We can think ahead to plant seeds now to organize our land, to let land rest after understanding soil depletion so that we can have a better harvest next year and I've realized that this love of planning and stability along with my rejection of the tradition that was brought to me that was teaching me how to open the eye of the heart. limited me from being able to explore in an open way, and the only way that's real on the tight rope of life to keep my eyes focused on beauty and to walk without looking down knowing and not knowing that the next step is going to land and that will be okay and that will make it. because the rope is invisible to the tight rope walker. It's just sensed, just like the worm is invisible to the bird. and in the muslin tradition were given many promises of what happens to those who trust and have god consciousness that these are those that are successful.  And these beliefs I think must be taken gradually, step by step. You take one step, that proves the rope is there, you leave one morning, you find the worms, but winter comes, things change, the wind blows, and the rope moves ever so slightly. and so I believe that it's not that we must avoid planning planting the seeds and using our mind, but that we need as a society to traverse this canyon. We are in a place where our stasis is destructive, our not changing is damaging, and I believe the roots of why staying the same is damaging is connected to the roots that have alienated us from this perception of beauty and truth and goodness, and even trusting that this means something that it's not an emotion only that it may have states ways that are uplifting inspire us.  You watch a movie about Nelson Mandela and you leave uplifted the sense of possibility and hope and maybe you think to yourself, how can I be a little more like that? And so the first thing that happened to me after my partner broke up with me because I could not face the fear. of the reality that was being that was beckoning the reality of I love this person and I don't know what to do. I'm young I don't know my faith.  I don't know myself. I don't know what love actually means. that love is the splendor of truth and that beauty and truth and love come together and that if I wanted to know God and how to live I have to read all three books the book of revelation, the book of inner insight and looking within our feelings, our thoughts, even our negative ruminations, and the book of the outer world the beauty of a river flowing down a mountain and a waterfall, and fish below in a clear pond eating the bugs on the river and then if you follow that river as it passes through human civilization on the other side, you look again into the water, and you find ugliness, a weird slimy color, a film on the top of the water potentially dead fish, a bad smell it repulses you. and why is that the case? How is this also true and how is that assign?  These signs of repulsion could have prevented us from continuing down this path the they would say the smell of London in the 1800s the squalor the tight neighborhoods with sewage flowing down the middle and Jack the Ripper and the pollution bellowing into the air and kids coming home in the morning after working at night shift in a factory and injuries and I'm sure people knew this wasn't beautiful. yet it helped increase the sense of control because there was a a power to it that could be grown resources accumulating into the hands of the owners allowing more allocating according to their desires and whims, unchecked and unpurified and unhe held up against the example of beauty and this alienation from the things that make life meaningful, require us to fill it with a hope that the future will be better. I don't feel so good right now, but I believe in this progress that we're making, this idea of progress links in deeply with this idea of how the reward system within us works. our sense of accomplishments and reward and the molecule dopamine that symbolizes it is not from achievement. It's not from making a goal and accomplishing it.  The reward comes from the expectation of a good, and so as long as we were able to tell ourselves in each other, this world might not be good to day, but to morrow it will be better when technology improves when we're able to extract more from less when we have to work less, this claim that, you know, we increase productivity and somehow work less and enjoy more is not what has happened at all. We've increased productivity and working hours, and at the same time we're reducing wages. This confusion about what is good, what do we want from life, this sense of mastery has been possible for only 200300 years and it was made possible from the primary disconnect from people with some their core faculty that is able to see and then the practice of implementing the seeing of beauty into a cycle of life that shows that you can take another step on that tight rope towards a more beautiful future and instead we went into a command and control into a cycle of allowing the things that think a we are able to control our situation and preserve our station and expand our domination and to manage people and the planet and the colonies and to do all of this in a way where we start having the science of productivity and the science of the polity and political science and we have this illusion of being able to get what we want without ever opening the eyes within us that can know what we actually want, and with only one eye, we can only see what we think we want, our needs, our fears, our expectations, and we try to address those, but it's it's a bottomless pit because the only thing that can really fill those is the eye that is able to see our true desires for love, beauty, connection, and the things that are truly satisfying.  And so what happens as we fall into lust or we fall into gluttony, or we fall into laziness, and we build escalators, and then when our bodies start falling apart, we go to the gym. And so understanding that dohamine is this reward molecule, I think is really important to see why we always imagine heaven as to morrow and that promise that things will be better, I think, kept people in a cage of anticipation and patience. of gritting our teeth kind of patience, but then, as we see in to day's world, we see that our uncontrolled, desire for control has expanded our unbeautiful ways of being into manipulating more of the world into ugliness into factories that fall on the people working to make our clothes and into promoting consumption just to be able to maintain the systems into this problematic situation that we find ourselves in that I think really is exemplified by this disconnect between this faculty that knows what is actually good and beautiful rather than the faculty that sees and wants for oneself, it's the faculty that sees and in that seeing can be satisfied in the connection and relating and and then we can talk very plainly about the rise of suicide. uh being one of the leading causes of death for young people, the beginning of suicides in preteens, which is unthinkable and it is kind of vague sense of anxiety they say that in the last 30 years the levels of anxiety have skyrocketed around the world, and we're coming to a place where I think we have to open that other eye. # From Quality to Action: Reimagining Social Impact

Something profound happens when we trust people to recognize and act from quality. I witnessed this during our team retreats in Dubai - watching social entrepreneurs share their stories, seeing them come to tears as they described their work. In those moments, I saw how our current systems of goals, metrics, and monitoring often get in the way of the very thing we're trying to support: people naturally moving toward what's beautiful and true.

This isn't just about emotions or intuition. It's about a fundamental human capacity to recognize quality directly - like a master craftsperson knows exactly how much pressure to apply, or a gardener knows precisely when to water. We all have this capacity, but our systems often block it with fear, self-protection, and excessive control.

Consider two organizations that show what's possible when we trust this capacity:

At Buurtzorg in the Netherlands, nurses are trusted to provide care without layers of management and metrics. They organize in small, self-managing teams connected to their communities. The result? Better patient outcomes, 40% lower costs, and the highest healthcare worker satisfaction in the country.

At Sounds True, decisions are made through a "felt sense" of what's important, combining business acumen with deeper wisdom. They built a $60M publishing company by trusting both quality recognition and practical business sense, proving that spiritual values can drive real success.

These aren't just nice stories - they point toward a fundamentally different way of working. Instead of starting with goals and metrics, we start by creating conditions where people can recognize and act from quality. Instead of trying to control outcomes, we focus on removing what blocks natural movement toward beauty and truth.

This has profound implications for how we support social enterprises:

1. Trust quality recognition first
- Help people access their natural capacity to recognize what's beautiful and true
- Create conditions where this recognition can guide action
- Support people in working through what blocks this capacity

2. Build like gardeners
- Focus on creating conditions rather than controlling outcomes
- Trust natural unfolding while maintaining appropriate discipline
- Let measurement serve beauty rather than replace it

3. Learn through craft
- Develop skills through direct relationship and practice
- Value mastery and depth alongside innovation
- Create containers for meaningful work to emerge

The key insight is this: before we can effectively pursue social impact, we need to reconnect with our capacity to recognize quality directly. This isn't mystical - it's as practical as a craftsperson knowing their material or a gardener understanding their plants.

When we trust this capacity:
- Goals emerge from quality recognition rather than abstract planning
- Metrics serve beauty rather than replace it
- Systems support natural unfolding rather than forcing outcomes
- Work becomes meaningful rather than merely productive

The path forward isn't about abandoning goals or metrics - it's about putting them in proper relationship to quality recognition. Like a good gardener uses soil tests not to control but to support natural growth, we need systems that enhance rather than replace our capacity to recognize and act from quality.

For social impact organizations, this means:
1. Supporting people in accessing their quality recognition capacity
2. Creating conditions where natural movement toward beauty can emerge
3. Building relationships that enable authentic development
4. Measuring what serves beauty rather than what controls it

This isn't just idealistic - organizations like Buurtzorg and Sounds True prove it creates better results than control-based approaches. The question isn't whether this works, but whether we're ready to trust it.

I believe we are. I've seen it in the tears and stories of entrepreneurs in Dubai, in the natural movement toward beauty when we create the right conditions, in the results that emerge when we trust people's capacity to recognize and act from quality.

The future of social impact isn't in better control systems - it's in better supporting our natural capacity to recognize and move toward what's beautiful and true. Everything else follows from that.

I hope you’re both well. I’ve been on a long reflective journey since our last in-depth exchange—one that’s led me to new insights about how Bloom.pm could evolve. I’m writing this letter to share the broader themes emerging from my recent thinking, the questions that keep surfacing, and a sense of how we might practically move forward.

Where We Started
We began Bloom with a commitment to support social enterprises and accelerate positive impact. Over time, I’ve felt a growing tension: we champion human well-being, yet we’re often pulled into a system that treats people as “means” for impact metrics or for pleasing funders. In my previous letter, I described how this mechanistic view can lead to burnout and a sense that we’re missing something essential.

The conversation we’ve had (including my own personal soul-searching) sharpened a central hypothesis: meaningful transformation arises when we honor people—and ourselves—as ends in themselves, not just as tools to achieve “outcomes.”

New Insights & Themes
From Rigid Systems to Emergent Craft

In our discussions, the metaphor of craft kept recurring. Think of a skilled craftsperson: she learns from a master, refines her process, gains deep insight into her materials, and passes on what she’s learned. This is worlds apart from a “factory farm” approach of forced efficiency and top-down metrics. A craft mindset fosters relationship, creativity, and continuous learning—outcomes that can’t be forced through dashboards and “scaling strategies” alone.
Key Lesson: True quality (and real social impact) emerges when people have the space and guidance to master their “materials”—whether that’s actual raw materials, ideas, community relationships, or personal growth.
Meaning as the Foundation, Not an Afterthought

For too long, “meaning” has felt like a luxury in the social impact world: we might address it in a retreat or workshop but quickly return to strict KPIs, donor demands, or monthly milestones. Our deeper exploration suggests that meaning is what sustains us—it’s not a nice-to-have but the very fuel for perseverance, creativity, and human vitality.
Key Lesson: When people connect to meaning in their work, they often outperform any standard benchmarks. The results follow naturally, without us having to sacrifice authenticity or well-being.
Personal Journeys & Community Ties

My own experiences—whether it was opening my home in Beirut or grappling with which job to take—have shown me that we can’t measure everything that truly matters. Trust, relationships, and personal transformations happen in moments that don’t fit neatly into a spreadsheet.
And yet, the community that forms around these intangible “moments of meaning” is real. Many craft-like enterprises (from small food-production networks to large cooperatives) scale because relationships expand in a living network, not because a rigid plan forced them to.
A Different Role for Technology & Metrics

Our exploration reaffirmed that metrics aren’t evil—they’re just incomplete. They should serve as one tool among many. The same goes for technology: it can enhance relationships (think of platforms that connect local makers with local buyers) or degrade them (mass automation that alienates both workers and consumers).
Key Lesson: We don’t need to reject all measurement or all tech. Instead, we need to ensure they support—rather than replace—human judgment, community building, and “craft.”
Bloom as a Space for Crafting Human Potential

If we treat Bloom as a living system rather than a machine, a new approach to “acceleration” emerges. Instead of forcing external goals on participants, we can:
Help them recognize their ‘materials’ (their gifts, their communities, their lived experiences).
Facilitate relationships with peers, mentors, and “masters” they can learn from.
Create “practice spaces” where they build real-world capacity rather than chase numeric targets.
Provide the right technology, tools, and structures only when they genuinely enhance the craft.

Practical Redesign of Our Programs

How can we organize Bloom’s offerings so they feel less like a linear program (apply → pitch → graduate) and more like a living community of practice, where members continuously learn, share, and refine?
Might we formalize “master-apprentice” relationships or “craft circles” as part of Bloom’s accelerators?
Measuring Meaning Without Suffocating It

How do we track qualitative outcomes—like someone’s deeper sense of purpose or new relationships—without distorting them into hollow indicators?
Could we adopt “relationship metrics,” “quality-of-experience journaling,” or “story-based evaluations” that keep the focus on humans rather than spreadsheets?
Aligning With the Right Funders and Partners

Are there funders who already value these craft-like, relationship-based approaches?
How do we communicate that going slower and deeper sometimes yields more lasting and authentic impact?
Balancing Business Realities & Soul Work

Could a more craft-based approach (e.g., membership fees, small group intensives, collaborative R&D) be financially viable?
Technology as a Force Multiplier, Not Master

What specific tools might help us? For example, platforms that match mentors to mentees in a more nuanced way than “mentor speed dating”? Or shared digital spaces that allow real-time reflection and feedback?

Pilot a “Craft Accelerator” Track

Let’s pick a small group of entrepreneurs who resonate with deeper, more relational methods. Instead of traditional milestones, we’d track:

Involve them in a slower, deeper mentorship that fosters real transmission rather than quick “office hours.”
Story-Driven Metrics

Let participants document their own journeys, either through journaling or short reflection videos. We can gather these as a living tapestry of their progress.

Explore partnerships with funders open to alternative metrics.
Perhaps pilot a small membership-based approach or a collaborative R&D budget that trusts in the emergent outcomes from a truly engaged community.
Reflect, Adapt, Iterate

This letter isn’t a final plan—it’s an invitation to prototype. If we find synergy, we can scale it. If not, we’ll adapt. That’s the essence of an emergent, craft-like approach.

Dear Dara and Munir,

I want to share some realizations that have been crystallizing about our work at Bloom - insights that started as frustrations but have evolved into a vision for a different way forward.

## The Journey Here

The moment that first opened my eyes came in Dubai, watching Marie Claire share her work on feminine hygiene. As she described creating not just products but spaces for women to discuss what was considered shameful, the whole room moved to tears. It wasn't just her impact metrics that moved us - it was witnessing someone naturally moving toward what was beautiful and true.

This contrasted sharply with our own work at times - drawing hockey stick growth charts for platforms no one was using, building assessment tools instead of deepening relationships, staying silent about concerns to maintain harmony. I felt increasingly frustrated, yet struggled to articulate why. I thought maybe it was just mood or emotion, not recognizing it as a legitimate knowing that something was off course.

## What I've Come to See

We've been operating like a factory when we need to think like craftspeople. This isn't just metaphor - it points to a fundamentally different way of working:

From Individual to Relational Development:
- Instead of isolated exercises and abstract frameworks
- We need master-apprentice relationships and community learning
- Direct transmission of wisdom, not just information
- Guided exploration rather than random searching

From Programs to Practice Spaces:
- Instead of fixed curriculum and defined outcomes
- We need conditions that enable natural emergence
- Quality recognition over metric-driven development
- Natural timing rather than arbitrary deadlines

From Content to Transmission:
- Instead of information transfer and skill checklists
- We need wisdom sharing and living examples
- Direct experience over best practices
- Quality recognition over standard metrics

## What This Means for Bloom

1. Program Design:
- Build around masters, not just content
- Create practice communities
- Enable direct transmission
- Support natural timing

2. New Metrics:
- Quality recognition development
- Community integration
- Wisdom transmission
- Practice depth

3. Technology's Role:
- Support relationship, don't replace it
- Enable connection, don't control it
- Enhance practice, don't automate it
- Scale wisdom, not just information

## Practical Next Steps

I propose we pilot a "craft-based accelerator" with these elements:

1. Finding Masters:
- Identify people who embody quality in their domain
- Create conditions for direct transmission
- Enable real apprenticeship, not just mentoring

2. Practice Spaces:
- Replace workshops with "craft circles"
- Focus on direct experience and feedback
- Create conditions for natural emergence

3. New Metrics:
- Track quality recognition development
- Measure relationship depth
- Document wisdom transmission
- Note organic growth patterns

## The Bigger Vision

This isn't just about better programs - it's about a different way of supporting social impact:

Instead of trying to scale impact through:
- Rigid systems
- Standardized metrics
- Forced growth
- Technology replacement

We scale through:
- Quality recognition
- Direct transmission
- Natural emergence
- Enhanced relationships

## Questions to Explore Together

1. How do we identify and engage true "masters"?
2. What conditions enable natural emergence?
3. How do we measure without controlling?
4. What technology truly serves relationship?

## Personal Note

I realize this is a significant shift from our current approach. But watching entrepreneurs like Marie Claire, seeing what emerges when we trust people's natural movement toward quality, I'm convinced this is the direction we need to explore.

The choice isn't between practical impact and deep meaning - it's about recognizing that real impact emerges when we create conditions for people to recognize and act from quality.

I'd love to discuss how we might experiment with these ideas in our next accelerator cycle. Even a small pilot could help us learn what's possible when we trust this deeper way of working.

With hope and conviction,
Bilal

# Reconnecting with Quality: A Letter about Bloom's Future

Dear Dara and Munir,

I've been struggling to articulate something important about our work at Bloom. The clarity finally came through stories of beauty and meaning - like when I heard Father Greg Boyle explain his work with gang members not through impact metrics but simply because "they're my friends." This pointed toward a way of being that wasn't instrumental, that was beautiful, that I wanted to experience for myself.

## The Crisis I'm Seeing

I've felt increasing frustration and anger when not able to express meaningful ways of being at work. I was stifled from connecting deeply with teams, watching us build systems that were dead on arrival because they never had soul in them in the first place - designed from goal setting, ambition, funder interest, and requirements for tracking rather than authentic experiments and connection with people and true care for their inner lives.

My inability to articulate these feelings led me to be passive, silent, frustrated, small. This led to increasing anger, mostly with myself for not being clear about what was frustrating me about what Bloom was building. I wasn't brave enough. I felt social pressure to conform, thinking about the team not wanting to show divided leadership, wanting to "keep things afloat." I allowed my doubt (maybe I'm wrong) to squish my growing tension and feeling that we're going the wrong way.

## Moments of Clarity

The contrast became clearest in Dubai. I'll never forget Marie Claire talking about how women need tampons and a space to talk about feminine hygiene, sharing her journey into realizing this for herself and solving it for other women. Going from school to school installing dispensers, finding a way out of thin air, using waste material from agriculture to produce cheaper tampons, finding funding, creating accessibility. It wasn't just making things - it was establishing spaces to talk about things considered shameful in her society.

It was all so beautiful - seeing her gratitude, feeling like we were part of helping her find a community of supportive women, all surrounding her and crying too, each bearing gifts for each other, sharing hugs and smiles. It was wonderful.

But then I'd feel the system pulling against aliveness in our Bloom meetings, drawing hockey stick charts about our growth while NO ONE was using the platform. This wishful thinking, disconnection from reality, and fear (fear of realizing we built the wrong thing, fear that we wasted our savings, fear that we're so close to getting it right) led us to keep going. It was wrong. I knew it was wrong, yet I couldn't stop the train.

## My Own Pattern

I see this in myself too - I'm a hacker who builds first and connects second, knowing there's nothing alive in there. Just today I built a meaning expression app because technology is cool and because I can, somehow thinking if I build it it means I'm good enough to share something "valuable" because people like software. We keep trying to scale impact through platforms and metrics while missing the real human connection people need. We text instead of calling, want to "blast" emails to thousands, create systems with drop-offs at every stage instead of leaning into the connection and knowledge that grows from our spheres and through them to their spheres.

Look at the iNGOs - they're happy to give us jobs, yet are silent when it comes to keeping us alive (Palestinians and Lebanese). The goals, the SDGs, the plans - these things are dead on arrival. The reality of being responsive, being real, being caring, being human and humane is lost to organizations focused on the attainment of something.

## Examples Showing Another Way

But there are organizations showing a different path. Look at Buurtzorg in healthcare - they eliminated management hierarchies and metrics-based control, trusting nurses to directly perceive and respond to patient needs. The result? Better care, lower costs, happier workers. They spread to 25 countries not through forced scaling but because the model works.

Or think about traditional craft communities and indigenous economics - they understand cyclical time (not linear), think seven generations ahead (not retiring at 40), build relationships with a world of meaning (not treating humans and nature as resources to extract).

It's like the difference between a food forest and a factory farm. The factory farm is always waiting for the harvest, measuring inputs against projected outputs. But in the food forest, every moment is successful - even the decaying leaves in winter are doing exactly what they should.

## What This Could Mean for Bloom

I think what we're really doing at Bloom isn't what we say we're doing. We're not saving the world - we're helping people find community, develop confidence, learn, grow, find agency. And that's actually more beautiful and valuable than our metrics suggest.

What if instead of measuring:
- Platform engagement
- Growth projections
- Impact metrics
- Resource utilization

We measured:
- Moments of meaning
- Quality of relationships
- Wisdom transmission
- Community vitality

What if funding allowed us to go deeper, work with fewer, and support them as they worked it out, rather than pushing funding, expenditures, and movement that may be adding friction and doing things that'll need to be undone?

## A Path Forward

Here's how we could start:

1. Create More "Dubai Moments"
- Focus on real connection over platform metrics
- Let authentic stories guide our work
- Create spaces for tears and transformation
- Trust what naturally emerges

2. Change How We Work
- Pause platform development
- Start with direct relationships
- Build tools only when human connection demands it
- Let systems serve life, not control it

3. Transform Our Programs
- Replace workshops with "craft circles"
- Enable real apprenticeship
- Support natural community formation
- Trust organic development

I know this sounds like a big shift. Maybe we need to find other jobs to give us time to build the real thing we want to share with the world. Maybe we need time to reflect. Maybe our children happening, our contracts dwindling, isn't the time to rush. Maybe these are signs that we should slow down and think deeper.

Would you be open to exploring this together? Even a small experiment could show us what's possible when we trust this deeper way of working.

With hope and conviction,
Bilal

P.S. - Remember how I used to avoid saying "I love you" by asking for definitions? I've stayed quiet too long about this too. Maybe it's time to trust what we know is true, even if we can't put it perfectly in metrics.

You measure, but you also feel. Similarly, a gardener sets the right conditions—soil fertility, water, sunshine—then watches growth emerge. You cannot force a seed to sprout; you can only support its natural flourishing.

Attentiveness: The material (clay, wood, community) has its own story, and you must listen.
Timing and Rhythm: Rushing can ruin the piece; waiting too long can spoil it, too. In social impact, a sense of readiness is as crucial as speed.

Short-term “scale mania” might yield impressive stats but can erode deeper bonds and obscure systemic oppression, as we see in Palestine, India, or countless other contexts.

It wasn’t just Father Greg’s words that struck me; it was the entire ethos of the On Being podcast. The show invites guests who embody spiritual depth and relational insight. Listening to these interviews, I realized that much of modern philanthropic discourse is missing that deeper reflection. We speak of “empowering communities” yet rarely talk about our inward transformation or the spiritual dimension of care.
Authentic friendship, rooted presence, and moral clarity do more for social transformation than any set of metrics alone.

Bloom can transform into being an organization that co-runs programs that aim to help people rediscover meaning in work and life. We used to focus on performance dashboards—like a factory. But now I’m proposing adopting the crafting-a-garden approach:
Preparing the Soil (Community Readiness)

Planting the Seeds (Inviting Co-Creation)

Tending the Garden (Sustained Support)
Like a gardener who regularly checks moisture and weeds, we maintain ongoing relationships—coaching, reflection circles, genuine friendship. We honor participants’ autonomy and celebrate emergent growth.
Harvesting and Sharing (Reflecting on Results)
Of course we measure—numbers, surveys—but these metrics follow the meaning, not the other way around. We also gather stories, capturing the intangible transformations: self-confidence blossoming, communities forging new alliances, or entrepreneurs finding deeper alignment.
On the Edge of True Impact
When we treat social impact as craft, we realize we can’t solve all problems overnight. But we can stand with communities in a lifelong posture of solidarity. We can name injustices rather than burying them under “neutral” data. In that naming, in that presence, we keep seeds of hope alive.

Part VIII: Calling Forth a New Paradigm
So how do we shift from metrics mania to crafting a garden?
Practice Stereoscopic Vision
Keep your metrics if they help you see part of reality. But never lose the second eye: the moral, relational, or spiritual dimension that sees goodness, truth, beauty and possibilities for friendship.
Name Reality Clearly
Avoid euphemisms. If it’s genocide, call it genocide. If microfinance turns exploitative, say so openly. Authentic relationships thrive on honesty, not polite obfuscation.
Slow Down to Go Deeper
Slowing the pace allows you to “listen to the clay,” to sense a community’s soul. Rushing might create short-term outputs but often yields shallow or harmful outcomes.
Trust the Process of Craft
Accept that not everything can be a linear blueprint. Gardening has seasons; some seeds fail. Craft has trial and error; sometimes the material cracks. This is growth, not a series of guaranteed leaps.
Adopt the Gardener’s Long View
A gardener invests in the soil, knowing real harvests may come years later—or bless future generations. In social impact, facing crises that range from genocide to climate disasters, we must hold a long-range vision. Even small acts of genuine friendship, alignment with our perception of beauty, can ripple beyond our immediate horizon.

What tension do you feel when pressured for quick results?
Which relationships in your work might you deepen rather than “scale”?
Where might you stand in truth—calling out systemic violence or injustice—rather than quietly conforming to funder-friendly narratives?
Asking these questions is an act of reclaiming our second eye—the one that perceives depth and moral texture. It’s a necessary counterpart to the first eye of data analysis.

Conclusion: Trusting the Seeds, Crafting the Garden
Father Greg Boyle’s line—“They’re my friends”—remains a beacon for me. It teaches that relationship can’t be an afterthought. No matter how refined our metrics or how lofty our proposals, if we lose sight of shared humanity, we drift into the same mechanistic mindset we intended to oppose.
Crafting a garden of social impact means:
Tending relationships like precious seedlings.
Using skilled, attentive “craft” to shape solutions with communities, cultivating the context in the present moment - anticipating the “impact” in the future like a gardener planting seeds in the spring hopes for tomatoes in the summer, yet can’t ensure it.


This is not an easy path. Gardens demand consistent care; craft demands repeated practice and humility. But it’s the only path I’ve found that truly integrates rational analysis with moral imagination. We don’t discard numbers—we simply refuse to make them our God. Instead, we combine metrics with love, data with empathy, and structure with spirit. That is the heart of stereoscopic vision—two ways of seeing that yield a deeper perception of reality.
In the end, what we grow—in ourselves and our communities—may far surpass the limited ambitions of simple “outputs” and “outcomes.” We may witness genuine healing, solidarity, and creative flourishing where once only a graph or a donor report existed. We may craft gardens so fertile with attention, compassion, and truth that entire communities not only survive but truly come alive.
And that, I believe, is what real impact looks like.

Final Thought
When we stand next to someone—whether a refugee, a farmer crushed by debt, or a family in Palestine facing daily violence—and say, “You are not my data point; you are my friend,” we enact the very transformation we hope to see in the world. We show that life isn’t a mechanical series of inputs and outputs, but a shared tapestry of stories, joys, and struggles.
May we all become craftspeople and gardeners of this new paradigm—humans who measure thoughtfully but love wholeheartedly, who plant seeds of change with skilled hands and open hearts, cultivating relationships that outlast any spreadsheet.

# From Metrics to Meaning: A New Direction for Bloom

Dear Dara and Munir,

A few years ago, I heard Father Greg Boyle explain why he worked with gang members. When asked about his intentions, he didn't cite impact metrics or SDGs. He said simply: "They're my friends." That single line pierced through years of my own confusion about our work. It pointed toward a way of being that wasn't instrumental, that was beautiful, that I wanted to experience for myself.

## The Crisis I'm Seeing

This insight has become painfully clear as I watch iNGOs pour resources into "job creation" for Palestinian refugees, touting how many positions are funded or certificates distributed, while remaining silent about genocide. The metrics of "employment rates" become a shield avoiding deeper moral responsibility. We're measuring what's easy instead of seeing what matters.

I see this pattern in our own work too. I've stayed quiet too long about my growing sense that something is fundamentally wrong with how we're approaching impact. I let fear of looking unprofessional, fear of divided leadership, fear of failing keep me from speaking what I knew in my heart was true.

Look at our own pattern - drawing hockey stick charts while no one uses our platform, building assessment tools instead of deepening relationships. I'm part of this problem - I'm a hacker who builds first and connects second, knowing there's nothing alive in there. Just recently I built a meaning expression app because technology is cool and because I can, somehow thinking if I build it means I'm good enough to share something "valuable."

## Learning to See with Both Eyes

This mechanistic worldview - treating humans and nature as resources to extract, measuring everything while recognizing nothing - has deep historical roots. From Descartes splitting mind and body to post-WWII obsession with metrics and control, we've lost our capacity to see with both eyes - one for measurement, one for meaning.

I learned this lesson personally in 2004 when I met my wife. On paper, nothing added up - different language, different culture, planning to return to France. But I decided, finally, for once in my life, I'm not going to think my way into a relationship. When I held her, my shoulders dropped. I felt connected. There was a leaning towards, a yes.

Now I watch our baby grow, surprised and grateful at the beauty that unfolds when we ask not "what do I want?" but "what wants to happen?" We need both eyes - metrics and meaning, analysis and quality recognition.

## What Real Impact Looks Like

I saw this most powerfully in Dubai, watching Marie Claire work on feminine hygiene - going from school to school installing dispensers, finding ways out of thin air to use agricultural waste for cheaper tampons, creating spaces for women to discuss what was considered shameful. It was all so beautiful. I want to cry just thinking about it now - seeing her gratitude, feeling like we were part of helping her find a community of supportive women, all surrounding her with tears and hugs and gifts.

This is what real impact looks like - not just numbers hit but lives transformed through authentic relationship. Yet our current systems block this natural movement toward quality and meaning. We text instead of calling, want to "blast" emails to thousands, create systems with drop-offs at every stage instead of leaning into the connection and knowledge that grows from our spheres and through them to their spheres.

## A Different Way Forward

Look at organizations showing another path:

Buurtzorg in healthcare - they eliminated management hierarchies and metrics-based control, trusting nurses to directly perceive and respond to patient needs. The result? Better care, lower costs, happier workers. They spread to 25 countries not through forced scaling but because the model works.

Traditional craft communities and indigenous economics understand something we've forgotten - cyclical time (not linear), thinking seven generations ahead (not retiring at 40), building relationships with a world of meaning (not treating humans and nature as resources to extract).

## What This Could Mean for Bloom

I think what we're really doing at Bloom isn't what we say we're doing. We're not saving the world - we're helping people find community, develop confidence, learn, grow, find agency. And that's actually more beautiful and valuable than our metrics suggest.

Instead of operating like a factory, focused on outputs and efficiency, what if we worked like gardener-craftspeople? This means:

1. Preparing the Soil
- Focus on real connection over platform metrics
- Let authentic stories guide our work
- Create spaces for transformation
- Trust what naturally emerges

2. Planting with Care
- Build tools only when human connection demands it
- Start with direct relationships
- Enable real apprenticeship
- Support natural community formation

3. Tending the Garden
- Replace workshops with "craft circles"
- Trust organic development
- Measure what serves life
- Let wisdom emerge naturally

## Moving Forward

Maybe we need to find other jobs to give us time to build the real thing we want to share with the world. Maybe we need time to reflect. Maybe our children happening, our contracts dwindling, isn't the time to rush. Maybe these are signs that we should slow down and think deeper.

What if funding allowed us to go deeper, work with fewer, and support them as they worked it out, rather than pushing funding, expenditures, and movement that may be adding friction and doing things that'll need to be undone?

Would you be open to exploring this together? Even a small experiment could show us what's possible when we trust this deeper way of working.

With hope and conviction,
Bilal
